published_attributes.title: Intro
published_attributes.serialized_body:
What you will learn in this chapter

  • What question to ask a client before and during the first meeting.
  • Communication tips - how to talk to a client
  • How to setup Google Drive / Invision asset folders
  • Most frequent questions your client may ask

published_attributes.title: Intro
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Questions you should ask yourself before this stage

  • Did I gathered all the info before the first meeting with the client?
  • Do I understand client basic idea/need?

Which Stakeholders you will need at this stage

  • Client
  • Designer(s)
  • Business Development Representative
  • Project Manager
  • Developer(s)

Tools that can help you at this stage

  • Statista (check credentials in 1 password)
  • Similar Web (you can use free features)
  • Prolific for surveys https://www.prolific.co/ (get budget from BB/Toto)
  • Competitors benchmarking - Prioridata - (great for competitors benchmarking - check how we used it here)

published_attributes.title: 🔎 Before first meeting with the Client
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Your work begins far before you pick your pen and paper.  Preparation for the first meeting with the client marks the actual beginning of a design process. By being prepared and professional on the first call, you start building a relationship - the reward is vital, the client’s trust in your decisions. Together with the Project Manager organise the meeting and gather all project info. Ask PM, BD and devs - don’t make the client answering for the same question twice. You need to know:

  • 👉 Does the client have a working product?
    • If yes, consider product review before
  • 👉 Does the project has a clear scope?
    • Y/N (at this stage project should have already a scope  otherwise a Scoping Session is needed)
  • 👉 Is the project idea ready to be designed?
    • If you think that the project idea needs a review or a Product Design sprint, check procedures for other services.
  • 👉 What platform will it be designed for?
  • 👉 In the case of web design, will it be responsive?
  • 👉 Will it be developed by Netguru?

👉  What platform will it be designed for?
👉  In the case of web design, will it be responsive?
👉  Will it be developed by Netguru?

published_attributes.title: 🤝 First meeting with the Client - explaining the process
published_attributes.serialized_body: Product design is a process. The process includes iterations that will result in the improvements of the product or service. The final iteration is complete when the client’s goals and the users’ goals are achieved.

blocks.text: Product design is a process. The process includes iterations that will result in the improvements of the product or service. The final iteration is complete when the client’s goals and the users’ goals are achieved.

draft_attributes.title: 🤝 First meeting with the Client - explaining the process
draft_attributes.serialized_body: Product design is a process. The process includes iterations that will result in the improvements of the product or service. The final iteration is complete when the client’s goals and the users’ goals are achieved.

blocks.text: Product design is a process. The process includes iterations that will result in the improvements of the product or service. The final iteration is complete when the client’s goals and the users’ goals are achieved.

published_attributes.title: 🤝 First meeting with the Client - explaining the process
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Educate Client on our design process

Educate the client about your role and your expectations. Establish the boundaries and expectations at the beginning. Give a quick overview of all the Product Design phases. Examples → What to expect from a designer, What are you paying for, Explaining the Design Process

Avoid multi-platform design at early stages of the project

If the client needs a multi-platform design, ask another designer for help. If you believe that the scope is big enough, always suggest a design team. Examples → Why a Team Approach Is the Key to Successful Product Design,

published_attributes.title: 🤝 First meeting with the Client - explaining the process
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Emphasize that it’s impossible to predict users’ behaviour accurately

We rely on the research and available data – the validity of a solution can only be assessed with relevant tests.

We cannot guarantee a business success

Try to make it clear that even the best product design does not guarantee a product’s success in terms of revenue.

More tips 👉 First contact with the client Any questions❓ Feel free to ask on #design-business

published_attributes.title: 📁 Design files organisation
published_attributes.serialized_body: When you start a new project, make sure that you have created “Design(er)” folder in the main client’s GDrive folder. If the project contains more design phases (Branding, Illustrations Product Design) or different products (Webapp, Mobileapp, Landing Page), divide the folder into appropriate subfolders. Each sub-folder should be properly structured.

blocks.text: When you start a new project, make sure that you have created “Design(er)” folder in the main client’s GDrive folder. If the project contains more design phases (Branding, Illustrations Product Design) or different products (Webapp, Mobileapp, Landing Page), divide the folder into appropriate subfolders. Each sub-folder should be properly structured.

If the project contains more design phases (Branding, Illustrations Product Design) or different products (Webapp, Mobileapp, Landing Page), divide the folder into appropriate subfolders. Each sub-folder should be properly structured.

published_attributes.title: 📁 Design files organisation
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Preparation

Subfolder structure

01_Sources

Each folder (Visual and Wireframes) should contain all sources files (psd, sketch etc.). It depends on the project, but if you have got two files of sources you should create subfolders for .psd, .sketch and any other extensions.

Each source file should be presented as a preview in .jpg or .png format.

02_Fonts

In this folder, you should put all the fonts which you use in the project, even if they are free. They should be grouped by font name.

03_Assets&Exports

Folder for FrontEnd Developers - should contain two subfolders:

Assets - all additional assets which you couldn’t put in exports. For example SVG icons etc.

Exports - all exports from Sketch or Photoshop. Remember to use plugins like Sketch Measure, Marketch. More information here.

04_Images

If you have got some external images (for example Shutterstock etc.) or icon sets you should upload them here.

05_Documentation

All documents related to this specific project. It can be personas, user stories etc.

You should create here also “Initial interview” sub-folder to collect most important data collected during an initial interview, materials sent by the client or scoping session notes related to design phase that is relevant to the project.

IMPORTANT! On the end of the project you should create a list of all screens with URL’s to particular screens on InvisionApp divided into different platforms, breakpoints etc (Handover document).

published_attributes.title: ✅ Best Practices - communication tips
published_attributes.serialized_body:
#1 General rules

  • Be active - recommend solutions
  • Listen to the expectations of the client
  • Consult your solutions with developers from day one
  • Make sure to explain how to use communication tool (eg. comments in Invision, eventually explain difference about tour-points and comments)
  • Know the benefits and outcomes of your work.
  • Gain client’s trust - then they will care about your opinions
  • Remember that often your client’s future depends on you, your decisions and your work. Everything you do serves to convince them.
  • Every decision you make must match the business goals of your client - always and foremost.
  • Use structure: [What you did]  +  [how you come up with the thing you did]  +   [why you did it / how this will help client’s business]
  • There are no maybe's, there is confidence -be absolutely sure about your statements
  • Tell about “whys” of your design and how it increases their business’ chances to succeed.
  • Use data - when you assume something, base it on good practices, behaviour studies, statistics.
  • It’s much better to present a small number of great arguments than flood the client with dozens of mediocre ones
  • Adjust your language
  • Don’t be passive
  • Don’t be afraid to ask but…
  • Don’t ask the basic questions that can be easily found in Google.
  • Avoid mythical users - First and foremost care about the client’s business. Our clients often have no users and a limited amount of money.
  • No maybe’s
  • Don’t talk about the things the client can see on their own. Say it this way: “This element is placed here because it will help X achieve/with Y”
  • Don’t use jargon

blocks.text: #1 General rules
Be active - recommend solutions
Listen to the expectations of the client
Consult your solutions with developers from day one

Make sure to explain how to use communication tool
(eg. comments in Invision, eventually explain difference about tour-points and comments)
Know the benefits and outcomes of your work.
Gain client’s trust - then they will care about your opinions
Remember that often your client’s future depends on you, your decisions and your work. Everything you do serves to convince them.
Every decision you make must match the business goals of your client - always and foremost.

Use structure:
[What you did]  +  [how you come up with the thing you did]  +   [why you did it / how this will help client’s business]
There are no maybe's, there is confidence -be absolutely sure about your statements
Tell about “whys” of your design and how it increases their business’ chances to succeed.
Use data - when you assume something, base it on good practices, behaviour studies, statistics.
It’s much better to present a small number of great arguments than flood the client with dozens of mediocre ones
Adjust your language
Don’t be passive
Don’t be afraid to ask but…
Don’t ask the basic questions that can be easily found in Google.
Avoid mythical users - First and foremost care about the client’s business. Our clients often have no users and a limited amount of money.
No maybe’s
Don’t talk about the things the client can see on their own. Say it this way: “This element is placed here because it will help X achieve/with Y”
Don’t use jargon

published_attributes.title: ✅ Best Practices - communication tips
published_attributes.serialized_body:
#2 Feedback

  • Be sure the client have time to give you feedback - if not try to ask for active stakeholders that can actively participate in the communication.
  • Make the client aware of the value of an active and collaborative approach (feedbacks, communication)
    • Make sure that there is only one final point of feedback from the client side
    • Make sure that have the opportunity to present your solutions to all of the stakeholders.
    • Make sure that client knows that we don’t work in a fixed number of reviews but in constant feedback and iteration mode.
  • Don’t wait til last moment to gather feedback
  • Don’t agree blindly to all feedback you’re receiving

Make the client aware of the value of an active and collaborative approach (feedbacks, communication)
Make sure that there is only one final point of feedback from the client side
Make sure that have the opportunity to present your solutions to all of the stakeholders.
Make sure that client knows that we don’t work in a fixed number of reviews but in constant feedback and iteration mode.
Don’t wait til last moment to gather feedback
Don’t agree blindly to all feedback you’re receiving

published_attributes.title: ✅ Best Practices - communication tips
published_attributes.serialized_body:
#3 Previous experience

  • Educate client on design good practices and basic principles during your meetings.
  • Be sure to address client’s concerns - what are the experiences of a client working with the designers?
  • Don’t assume client understand design process

Don’t assume client understand design process

published_attributes.title: ✅ Best Practices - communication tips
published_attributes.serialized_body:
#4 Milestones & priorities

  • Make sure that the client has a reasonable approach for the making an MVP (keeping the scope small)
  • Make the client aware of the importance to go step by step in terms of functionalities.
  • Don’t agree to extend the scope without discussing it with the client and the Team

blocks.text: #4 Milestones & priorities
Make sure that the client has a reasonable approach for the making an MVP (keeping the scope small)
Make the client aware of the importance to go step by step in terms of functionalities.
Don’t agree to extend the scope without discussing it with the client and the Team

Make sure that the client has a reasonable approach for the making an MVP (keeping the scope small)
Make the client aware of the importance to go step by step in terms of functionalities.

published_attributes.title: ✅ Best Practices - communication tips
published_attributes.serialized_body:
#5 Selling your work

  • Gain client’s trust in your decision - back them up with research
  • Know the “whys” behind your design decisions
  • Don’t hesitate when client ask about your “whys”

published_attributes.title: ❓ Q&A
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Questions your client may ask at this stage

Why do you want to know the business model? This will allow us to work within proper constraints and tailor proper design solutions.

Why do you have to know this stuff before we meet? This will allow us to prepare better and have a more focused meeting.

We don't have: (business analysis, market research, target audience) Can you do this for us? We can help you with some parts of it

published_attributes.title: ❓ Q&A
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Questions you should ask yourself after this stage

  • Do I know project requirements and problems to solve?
  • Do I know what will make the project a success?
  • Do I understand the client business?
  • Do I know if the client understands his business?
  • Do I have gathered answers for design/business related questions?
  • Do I have folder structure set on Google Drive?
  • Do I know and gathered all materials available from a client (including brand guides etc)?

Do I have folder structure set on Google Drive?
Do I know and gathered all materials available from a client (including brand guides etc)?
